div.sent: Every animal is different from one another.
In spite of differences in size and look, some of the basic functions are same in all animal cells;
such as digestion, respiration, movement, excretion, response to stimuli, growth, reproduction and death.
Besides, every animal has its own characteristic design; which is inherited from their parents.
To perform these functions different organs and structures are there.
For example, digestive system, lungs, heart, blood vessels, bone, muscles, kidney, brain, nerve, reproductive system etc.
These organs and structures are developed from different types of cells.
So, cell is called the structural unit of living body of organisms.
To build a brick house, bricks, cements and sands are needed.
A building is constructed by setting bricks one after another.
In case of animals, body is built by a large number of cells together.
But all cells are not of same size.
To perform different functions, size and nature of cells differ from each other.
For example, muscle cells are elastic and flexible.
But the cells forming bones are strong and nonflexible.
You should have more knowledge about a biological cell.
Cells of different animals are same but characteristic designs are different and unique for every species of animal.
Genes are arranged in a linear fashion on the chromosomes in a cells.
These genes bear the characteristics of the species.
In a normal cell a piece of protoplasm is surrounded by a cell membrane.
It contains cytoplasm and nucleus.
Organelles like mitochondria, golgi complex, ribosome, endoplasmic reticulum etc. are present in the cytoplasm.
Chromosomes are borne inside the nucleus.
Genes are arranged in a row on the chromosome and bear the characteristics of the species.
For these reasons, children inherit characters of their parents.
From above discussion now you can realize the importance of cells in a living body.
Structural and functional unit of organism is the cell.
Cytoplasm bounded by a membrane and controlled by nucleus, is called a cell.
A piece of protoplasm with all the characteristics for expression of life, is called a cell.
When a group of cells in multicellular organisms perform a definite function: it is called a tissue.
Ultimate goal of these cells are same but they may vary in size and shape.
It depends on the nature of function of the cell and tissue.
Animal body is build up with different types of tissues, such as Epithelial tissue Muscular tissue Connective tissue Nerve tissue Reproductive tissue.
Outer covering of our skin and internal lining of our mouth etc. are composed of epithelial tissue.
Different glands are also composed of epithelial tissue.
Cells of epithelial tissue are arranged in one or two layers.
Cells are arranged closely on basement membranes.
In this type of tissue there is no intercellular matrix.
Functions of epithelial tissue Main function of this tissue is protection and covering.
It protects internal and external organs from injury.
Some cells of this tissue participate in secretion.
Taste, such as cover cells of tongue.
Excretion, such as cover cells of renal tubules.
Animal tissues having the ability of contraction and expansion are called muscular tissues.
Based on position, structure and function, they are of three types.
Voluntary or striated muscles When contraction and expansions of muscles depend on the will of the organism; it is called voluntary or striated muscles.
They are connected with bone, such as biceps muscle, triceps muscle etc. the jaw moves because of contraction and expansion of these voluntary muscles.
Voluntary muscles are elastic and have capacity of expansion.
The cells of these muscles have transverse black and white stripes (striated).
Cells of these muscles have more than one nucleus.
It becomes compressed when excited.
The cells of these muscles are covered with a layer, called circolemma.
Functions of voluntary muscles It helps in movement of different organs and organelles.
It helps in movement of the animal.
Involuntary or smooth muscles When contraction and expansion of muscles are not dependent on the will of the organism is called involuntary or smooth muscles;
such as muscles of stomach, intestine, kidney etc. Involuntary muscles do not have transverse black and white stripes.
Each cell with only one nucleus.
There is no circolemma.
Each cell is long and spindle shaped.
These muscles show rhythmic move- ment when contract and expand.
Function of involuntary muscles Capacity of contraction is mild and rhythmic.
Food move through digestive canal due to contraction of intestinal muscles.
It is a special type of involuntary muscle.
The heart is built with this type of muscles.
Characterstics of cardiac muscles Cardiac muscles are lightly striped.
These muscles are branched.
Fibres of cardiac muscles are small and cylindrical.
Interconnected with each other by lateral branches.
Functions of cardiac muscles Contraction and expansion of cardiac muscles cause circulation of blood through the heart to the rest of the body.
To make the heart contract and expand in a rhythm.
Connective Tissue This tissue connects different tissues and organs, such as blood, bone, cartilage, fat cells etc.
This muscle cells originate from mesoderm of the embryo.
Cells of these muscles are not arranged in a definite layer.
These cells secrete large amount of noncellular matrix and stored in intercellular spaces.
In this muscle, number of cells is less but amount of matrix is high.
Cells of this muscle is modified variously to perform different functions.
The matrix substance of bones is calcium.
Bones make the structure, bear weight and give rigidity of the body.
Tendon connects muscles with bones.
Fibrous connective tissue help in expansion and contraction of lungs and blood vessels.
Loose connective tissue work as filler in the gaps in between two organs.
Fat cells store fats.
Cartilages are strong but elastic.
Blood transports different substances (oxygen, food, nitrogenous wastes) from one place to another.
Beside, this blood resist microbes causing diseases.
The matrix of blood is a fluid.
Tissue that can respond to stimuli and produce sensation is called nerve tissue.
The unit of nerve tissue is nerve cell or neuron.
The brain is made of neuron.
Each neuron is composed of three parts; Cell body: It is the main portion of nerve cell.
Its shape varies, such as elliptical, star-like, round etc.
Each cell contains one nucleus.
b) Dendron: The branches arise from all arround the cell body are called dendrons.
Branches from dendrone are called dendrites.
c) Axon: A long, unbranched and thread like structure arising from the cell body is called axon.
Its length may be from 1 mm to few meters.
Axon means axis.
Axon is covered with a structure neurilemma.
The axon of neurone is connected with a branch of dendron.
By interconnecting a large number of neurons a nerve is formed.
The connecting point of axon and dendron is called synapse.
Stimulus coming through this synapse to dendrone from adjacent nerve cell.
1) When responding to stimuli it sends impulses from different sense organs and sensitive parts to different parts of the body.
2) Relevant parts of the body respond to this stimuli.
For example, when mosquito bites, the impulse is sent to the brain.
The brain inform the hand and the hand try to kill the mosquito.
3) It retains these impulses and the facts in the memory.
4) It co-ordinates among different physiologic activities of the body.
